Award.AwardTitle: Structural characterization of rod phosphodiesterase 6 using mass spectrometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program is supporting the collaborative research of Drs. Feixia Chu and Rick Cote at University of New Hampshire on the structural characterization of a central phototransduction effector enzyme, photoreceptor phosphodiesterase-6 (PDE6). PDE6 modulates cGMP levels in the photoreceptor outer segment to define the amplitude, duration and adaptation of the photoresponse in vertebrate photoreceptors. This study aims to elucidate the structural determinants of PDE6 allosteric regulators, the spatial organization and molecular recognition of the dynamic PDE6 signaling complex. This research is interdisciplinary, involving the combination of mass spectometry and protein biochemistry to study the underlying structural elements that govern the PDE6 activation/deactivation cycle.

This work is expected to both shed light on key events in the visual cycle and the molecular level, focusing on a key protein involved in signal transduction. In a more general sense, the work is expected to lead to strategies and methods to detect protein conformational change, especially in structurally heterogeneous systems, with potentially applicability to technically challenging membrane proteins and protein complexes. The interdisciplinary nature of this project will expose undergraduate and graduate students and a postdoctoral trainee to a broad set of skills at the interface of biochemistry, mass spectrometry-based proteomics and structural analysis. In addition to the proposed research, the research team personnel will continue to participate in education and outreach efforts at the Chemistry/Biology interface at the University of New Hampshire.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Photoreceptor phosphodiesterase 6 (PDE6) is the central effector enzyme in visual excitation pathway in rod and cone photoreceptors. Its tight regulation is essential for the speed, sensitivity, recovery and adaptation of visual detection. Although major steps in the PDE6 activation/deactivation pathway have been identified, mechanistic understanding of PDE6 regulation is limited by the lack of knowledge about the molecular organization of the PDE6 holoenzyme (αβgg) and its modulation by allosteric regulators. This gap in knowledge is due to the difficulties of studying protein complexes confined to the membrane, as well as of obtaining quantities of PDE6 holoenzyme and PDE6 complex needed for crystallographic studies.

In this study, we utilize chemical cross-linking and mass spectrometric analysis (CXMS) to structurally characterize PDE6 effector enzyme. The CXMS approach can identify amino acid residues in spatial proximity but distant in primary sequence, providing intermediate resolution information on relative domain positions and orientations. Our results are in excellent agreement with several high-resolution structures for individual domains of phosphodiesterase superfamily enzymes, supporting the biochemical and functional relevance of our data. Based primarily on our CXMS data, in conjunction with related crystallographic structures and an EM density map, we build a model of the PDE6 holoenzyme. Our model elucidates an overall molecular architecture resembling the crystal structure of a homologous protein PDE2. However, the substantial differences in catalytic domain arrangement implicates the mechanism for a diffusion-controlled PDE6 catalysis, distinct from other PDE enzymes.

Furthermore, we use a label-free quantitative CXMS analysis to compare the conformation of PDE6 in the presence of allosteric regulators, noncatalytic cGMP and inhibitory Pg subunit. Our results reveal significant changes in physiochemical properties of residues around catalytic sites upon the binding of inhibitory Pg subunit, as expected. Furthermore, we detect two different binding modes of the inhibitory Pg subunit to the regulatory GAFa domain of the catalytic a- and b-subunit, in which noncatalytic cGMP binding enhances the interaction between the GAFa domain of Pa and Pg subunit. Our results provide molecular insights on the fine-tuning of each catalytic subunit in photoreceptor activation/deactivation at different cellular cGMP levels. The label-free quantitative CXMS approach we develop for this study is widely applicable to the structural analysis of other proteins and protein complexes.

The interdisciplinary nature of this project provides unique opportunities for the joint training of undergraduate and graduate students and a postdoctoral trainee in a broad set of skills at the interface of biochemistry, mass spectrometry-based proteomics and structural analysis. In addition to this project, the PI, co-PI and their group members have been active members of the local community in disciplinary education. They have participated in various out-reach activities, including the Northern New England Junior Science and Humanities Symposia, Nottingham School Science Fair, Project Smart Summer Institute to engage middle school and high school students and underrepresented groups in the STEM field. The PI serves on the Undergraduate Research Committee of the American Society of Mass Spectrometry, the review panels of NSF Graduate Research Fellowship Program. 

 


Last Modified: 10/31/2017
Modified by: Feixia Chu
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Photoreceptor phosphodiesterase 6 (PDE6) is the central effector enzyme in visual excitation pathway in rod and cone photoreceptors. Its tight regulation is essential for the speed, sensitivity, recovery and adaptation of visual detection. Although major steps in the PDE6 activation/deactivation pathway have been identified, mechanistic understanding of PDE6 regulation is limited by the lack of knowledge about the molecular organization of the PDE6 holoenzyme (αβgg) and its modulation by allosteric regulators. This gap in knowledge is due to the difficulties of studying protein complexes confined to the membrane, as well as of obtaining quantities of PDE6 holoenzyme and PDE6 complex needed for crystallographic studies. In this study, we utilize chemical cross-linking and mass spectrometric analysis (CXMS) to structurally characterize PDE6 effector enzyme. The CXMS approach can identify amino acid residues in spatial proximity but distant in primary sequence, providing intermediate resolution information on relative domain positions and orientations. Our results are in excellent agreement with several high-resolution structures for individual domains of phosphodiesterase superfamily enzymes, supporting the biochemical and functional relevance of our data. Based primarily on our CXMS data, in conjunction with related crystallographic structures and an EM density map, we build a model of the PDE6 holoenzyme. Our model elucidates an overall molecular architecture resembling the crystal structure of a homologous protein PDE2. Furthermore, we detect two different binding modes of the inhibitory Pg subunit to the regulatory GAFa domain of the catalytic a- and b-subunit, in which noncatalytic cGMP binding enhances the interaction between the GAFa domain of Pa and Pg subunit. Our results provide molecular insights on the fine-tuning of each catalytic subunit in photoreceptor activation/deactivation at different cellular cGMP levels. The label-free quantitative CXMS approach we develop for this study is widely applicable to the structural analysis of other proteins and protein complexes. The interdisciplinary nature of this project provides unique opportunities for the joint training of undergraduate and graduate students and a postdoctoral trainee in a broad set of skills at the interface of biochemistry, mass spectrometry-based proteomics and structural analysis. In addition to this project, the PI, co-PI and their group members have been active members of the local community in disciplinary education. They have participated in various out-reach activities, including the Northern New England Junior Science and Humanities Symposia, Nottingham School Science Fair, Project Smart Summer Institute to engage middle school and high school students and underrepresented groups in the STEM field. The PI serves on the Undergraduate Research Committee of the American Society of Mass Spectrometry, the review panels of NSF Graduate Research Fellowship Program.
